Last Chance
The Student Council is now reaching completion of
the long awaited and much heralded revision of their
constitution. Before the gate shuts for good, several comments and suggestions are in order.
The first point to be made is that this new constitution should finally end the reign of the autonomous
student bodies on this campus which in large part dominate student life. Included in these are the Booster Club,
the Cotillion Board, and the BIA.
The reasons for this are two-fold. In the first place
these groups are too often and too blatantly controlled or
influenced by fraternities. In each of these groups one or
more fraternities has carved out of student government
their own private shiekdom which they are able to maintain from year to year.
Secondly, the avowed purpose of the Student Council is to govern the campus not to give away its powers. If
the SC is ever to function it must have at least some of
the powers that are currently in the hands of these
groups.
The second point is that somewhere in the new SC
Constitution provision should be made for the establishment of a non-academic judiciary board. The need of
such a body has been demonstrated time and again. This
is the chance to give it life.
Thirdly, and most important is the need for the new
constitution to protide real representation for the Hopkins student. At the moment once the ballot has been
cast, usually on the basis of the best or funniest sign, all
representation ceases. The student has no means of initiating legislation or approving the legislation passed.
He has no idea of what his so called representative thinks
or what he plans to do. In effect the present system provides for misrepresentation rather than representation.
There are three ways to remedy this situation. The
first of these is recall. But this would hardly be an adequate solution. The sound remedy is referendum on
major issues. While this would allow the students to voice
their opinion on measures passed, it still would not give
them an opportunity to make new suggestions:
The third and most feasible solution would be the
establishment of political parties on campus. A member
of such a party would be bound to carry out the party
platform and would respect the wishes and suggestions
of the members of his party. Thus true representation
would be achieved in the Student Council.

The "Socialist" Question
The recent flurry of charges and counter-charges
over the distribution of "socialist" literature has stimulated a good deal of incoherent and confused discussion
of this "socialism." By way of clarification, we shall
add our piece and hope that it doesn't contribute too
much to the confusion.
The newspaper The Young Socialist is a publication of the "Young Socialist Alliance," the Baltimore
chapter of which is attempting to distribute the newspaper and other literature on the Johns Hopkins campus.
The "Young Socialist Alliance" (YSA) is more or less
affiliated with the Socialist Workers Party (SWP), a
national political party whose program has been described as Trotskyist. The SWP should not be confused
with the Socialist Party, led in America by the venerable
Norman Thomas. The Socialist Party and its youth offspring the "Young Peoples Socialist League" (YPSL)
are bitterly opposed by the YSA—generally for being
too conservative.
We cannot as yet discern clear evidence that the
administration of this University is engaged in a concerted effort to restrict the free dissemination of YSA
convictions. A blanket ban on the distribution of this
literature because the ideas presented are unpopular
would indeed draw our vigorous editorial opposition.
However, we fail to see that the administration has enjoined the YS4 from free distribution and consequently

The small, unobtrusive, halfhidden building situated near
the dormitories and simply

Handbook, has been in use continually since 1929 by classes of
the Hopkins evening and summer schools.
Built in that year under the
direction of an English astronomer, Dr. Reginald Waterfield,
the brick structure was a greatly appreciated improvement over
the former location of the telescope on the roof of the old
downtown physics building.
The telescope itself has a ten
inch lens and was acquired very
early in the existence of the
University. Only for a short
period after 1884, however, was
it used by Hopkins day school
classes, and this was done under
the guidance of Dr. Simon Newcomb, a distinguished scientist
holding the position of Professor
of Mathematics and Astronomy.
Quite new in comparison to

the telescope, the astronomy
building has a sliding room section giving access to a viewing
area sufficient for present teaching needs. These consist solely
of McCoy College classes taught
by Mr. Jean Berlijn of the
Physics Dept. on Thursday
nights or exceptionally clear
evenings. In this connection,
photographs of sunspots and of
some of the planets have been
taken.

As of the moment, however, no
serious reqearch is being conducted with the aid of the astronomy building. This, according
to Professor G. H. Dieke, chairman of the Physics Dept., is due
to the great amount of atmospheric interference inherent in
a low-lying, industrial area such
as Baltimore, and to the wooded
surroundings of the campus itself, which cut off a large field
of vision needed free for fullscale research programs.

Last Chance
The Student Council is now reaching completion of
the long awaited and much heralded revision of their
constitution. Before the gate shuts for good, several comments and suggestions are in order.
The first point to be made is that this new constitution should finally end the reign of the autonomous
student bodies on this campus which in large part dominate student life. Included in these are the Booster Club,
the Cotillion Board, and the BIA.
The reasons for this are two-fold. In the first place
these groups are too often and too blatantly controlled or
influenced by fraternities. In each of these groups one or
more fraternities has carved out of student government
their own private shiekdom which they are able to maintain from year to year.
Secondly, the avowed purpose of the Student Council is to govern the campus not to give away its powers. If
the SC is ever to function it must have at least some of
the powers that are currently in the hands of these
groups.
The second point is that somewhere in the new SC
Constitution provision should be made for the establishment of a non-academic judiciary board. The need of
such a body has been demonstrated time and again. This
is the chance to give it life.
Thirdly, and most important is the need for the new
constitution to protide real representation for the Hopkins student. At the moment once the ballot has been
cast, usually on the basis of the best or funniest sign, all
representation ceases. The student has no means of initiating legislation or approving the legislation passed.
He has no idea of what his so called representative thinks
or what he plans to do. In effect the present system provides for misrepresentation rather than representation.
There are three ways to remedy this situation. The
first of these is recall. But this would hardly be an adequate solution. The sound remedy is referendum on
major issues. While this would allow the students to voice
their opinion on measures passed, it still would not give
them an opportunity to make new suggestions:
The third and most feasible solution would be the
establishment of political parties on campus. A member
of such a party would be bound to carry out the party
platform and would respect the wishes and suggestions
of the members of his party. Thus true representation
would be achieved in the Student Council.

too conservative.

administration of this University is engaged in a concerted effort to restrict the free dissemination of YSA
convictions. A blanket ban on the distribution of this
literature because the ideas presented are unpopular
would indeed draw our vigorous editorial opposition.

The small, unobtrusive, halfhidden building situated near
the dormitories and simply
labeled, "Astronomy," in the
Handbook, has been in use continually since 1929 by classes of
the Hopkins evening and summer schools.
Built in that year under the
direction of an English astronomer, Dr. Reginald Waterfield,
the brick structure was a greatly appreciated improvement over
the former location of the telescope on the roof of the old
downtown physics building.
The telescope itself has a ten
inch lens and was acquired very
early in the existence of the
University. Only for a short
period after 1884, however, was
it used by Hopkins day school
classes, and this was done under
the guidance of Dr. Simon Newcomb, a distinguished scientist
holding the position of Professor
of Mathematics and Astronomy.
Quite new in comparison to

the telescope, the astronomy
building has a sliding room section giving access to a viewing
area sufficient for present teaching needs. These consist solely
of McCoy College classes taught
by Mr. Jean Berlijn of the
Physics Dept. on Thursday
nights or exceptionally clear
evenings. In this connection,
photographs of sunspots and of
some of the planets have been
taken.

As of the moment, however, no
serious reqearch is being conducted with the aid of the astronomy building. This, according
to Professor G. H. Dieke, chairman of the Physics Dept., is due
to the great amount of atmospheric interference inherent in
a low-lying, industrial area such
as Baltimore, and to the wooded
surroundings of the campus itself, which cut off a large field
of vision needed free for fullscale research programs.
